metadata.sermon_title: Der Glaube arbeitet an der Angst
metadata.sermon_start_end: Diese Geschichte gehört unter die so genannten Naturwunder, d.h. Geschichten, die in der ausgehenden Antike sehr oft erzählt wurden von gottbegnadeten großen Männern, die die Kraft hatten, über die Natur zu bestimmen und etwa das Wetter zu ändern. Ich glaube aber, dass für uns die Durchbrechung der Naturgesetze nicht so interessant ist [...] Das Wort Jesu soll uns dahin bringen, dass auch wir eines Tages sagen können, in dieser Welt, die aus Konkurrenz und Aggression gemacht ist, haben wir Angst, aber wir gehören schon jetzt in eine neue andere Welt hinein. Wir, nicht nur Jesus, sondern wir alle, die dann Jesus Christus geworden sind.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses the pericope as a springboard for a psychological and sociological discourse. It fails to identify what is unique to this specific text. Instead of 'recreating the Bible into a new, current word,' it reduces the text to a general symbol for 'fear vs. faith.'
quotes: Ich glaube aber, dass für uns die Durchbrechung der Naturgesetze nicht so interessant ist wie vielleicht die Durchbrechung der Psychogesetze
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on the specific details of the Markan narrative—the sleeping Jesus, the rebuke of the wind—rather than immediately pivoting to general 'psychological laws' or global crises.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is almost entirely absent. The preacher dismisses the historical-redemptive significance of the 'nature miracle' as uninteresting for modern man. There is no engagement with the original Greek or the specific theology of the Gospel of Mark.
quotes: Diese Geschichte gehört unter die so genannten Naturwunder... d.h. Geschichten, die in der ausgehenden Antike sehr oft erzählt wurden
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Investigate the original context of the storm on the Sea of Galilee and the theological significance of 'rebuking' the sea in the Old Testament tradition.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist' (economic crisis, fascism, psychology), which Dekker values. However, it often drifts into general socio-political commentary that is not strictly derived from the text.
quotes: Ich brauche Sie nur zu erinnern an die Wachstumskrise... an die Bedrohung der Arbeitsplätze.
Ich habe von einer Arbeiterin gelesen, die an ihrem Arbeitsplatz an einer Maschine steht
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Tie the concrete contemporary examples directly to the movement of the text rather than using the text as a pretext for social analysis.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is heavily weighted toward application (psychology/sociology). The 'exposition' is treated as a hurdle to be cleared quickly to reach the 'real' topic of human fear. The hearer is not drawn into the text, but the text is dragged into the hearer's world.
quotes: Der Inhalt dieser Geschichte heißt Angst oder Glauben, und sie wirbt darum zu glauben.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the text's own logic to dictate the structure of the application, rather than imposing a psychological framework (psychoanalysis) onto the narrative.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery (fear, sin as separation) is strongly present. Redemption is present but tends toward human self-actualization ('working on fear') rather than a purely external act of God. Gratitude is less distinct.
quotes: Die Angst davor, von Gott verlassen zu werden, ist die tiefste Form der Trennungsangst.
Der Glaube nimmt die Angst an... Er bearbeitet sie.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Clarify that redemption is an act of Christ (the 'One Lord') upon the person, rather than a 'technique' for processing anxiety.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses the possibility of being 'lost in time' (social collapse, suicide). It takes the human condition seriously but lacks the 'narrow way' vs. 'broad way' urgency in a theological sense.
quotes: Angst vieler junger Menschen vor der Sinnlosigkeit, die sie in den Selbstmord führt
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Frame the choice between fear and faith not just as psychological health, but as a fundamental decision regarding one's destination before God.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned, but the sermon ends on a problematic note where the distinction between the Savior and the saved is blurred. Christ as 'brother' and 'friend' risks losing the 'One Lord' status Dekker demands.
quotes: Jesus ist nicht unser Herr, sondern unser Bruder und unser Freund.
Wir alle, die dann Jesus Christus geworden sind.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Maintain the 'doctrine of the two natures.' Christ must remain the 'telos' and the Lord who commands the storm, not merely a co-sufferer or a model for self-transformation.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1150 words, the sermon would take about 11-12 minutes. This is significantly below Dekker's 20-minute minimum. The lack of 'breadth' results in a lack of exegetical 'depth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the sermon by including rigorous exegetical work and a deeper exploration of the biblical text's unique claims.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its brevity and its subordination of Scripture to psychology. It lacks formal exegesis and fails to treat the Bible passage as a unique Word of God, opting instead to treat it as a general illustration of human anxiety. While it successfully engages with the 'zeitgeist' and the 'misery' of modern man, it risks becoming a psychological lecture rather than a proclamation of the Gospel.
strengths: Concrete social and psychological analysis of fear.
Serious treatment of 'misery' in the context of modern industrial society.
Avoidance of 'naive' faith that ignores the reality of human suffering.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (approx. 11 minutes) prevents necessary depth.
Theological blurring of the distinction between Christ and the believer in the conclusion.
Reduction of the specific biblical narrative to a general psychological archetype.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a religious-psychological speech. It lacks the 'exposition' of a specific passage and fails the length requirement necessary for substantive proclamation.
